mainmatter.p: A stationary state is a quantum state with all observables independent of time.
Refer to chapter 2 in Introduction to Quantum Mechanics

In previous section we use the Schrodinger equation to compute things. The variable tttt is annoying which makes things complicated, and we would like to get rid of it. In this section we shall assume that the potential energy VVVV is independent of time. In that case the Schrodinger equation becomes: i \hbar \frac { \partial }{ \partial t} \psi (x,t) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac { \partial ^2 \psi (x,t)}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) \psi (x,t) iℏ∂∂tψ(x,t)=−ℏ22m∂2ψ(x,t)∂x2+V(x)ψ(x,t) i \hbar \frac { \partial }{ \partial t} \psi (x,t) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac { \partial ^2 \psi (x,t)}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) \psi (x,t) iℏ∂t∂​ψ(x,t)=−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2ψ(x,t)​+V(x)ψ(x,t) This equation can be solved by separation of variables. We assume the spatial and time dependencies of the solution can be separated. In other words we look for solutions of the product form: \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x) \phi (t) Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)ϕ(t) \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x) \phi (t) Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)ϕ(t) This is an absurd restriction, but it works and we can get interesting results.

frontmatter.title: Time-independent Schrodinger Equation › Solve the equation

mainmatter.p: Now substitute the product form into the Schrodinger equation: i \hbar \psi (x) \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \phi (t) \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) \psi (x) \phi (t) iℏψ(x)∂∂t(ϕ(t))=−ℏ22mϕ(t)∂2(ψ(x))∂x2+V(x)ψ(x)ϕ(t) i \hbar \psi (x) \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \phi (t) \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) \psi (x) \phi (t) iℏψ(x)∂t∂​(ϕ(t))=−2mℏ2​ϕ(t)∂x2∂2(ψ(x))​+V(x)ψ(x)ϕ(t) Divide both sides by \psi (x) \phi (t)ψ(x)ϕ(t)\psi (x) \phi (t)ψ(x)ϕ(t): i \hbar \frac {1}{ \phi (t)} \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m \psi (x)} \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) iℏ1ϕ(t)∂∂t(ϕ(t))=−ℏ22mψ(x)∂2(ψ(x))∂x2+V(x) i \hbar \frac {1}{ \phi (t)} \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m \psi (x)} \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) iℏϕ(t)1​∂t∂​(ϕ(t))=−2mψ(x)ℏ2​∂x2∂2(ψ(x))​+V(x) Notice that the left side depends only on tttt and the right side depends only on xxxx. They are equal if and only if they are both equal to a constant. Otherwise if I change the left side and level the right side unchanged, I get a contradiction. The constant is the energy of the system, and we denote it by EEEE. E: \equiv i \hbar \frac {1}{ \phi (t)} \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) E:≡iℏ1ϕ(t)∂∂t(ϕ(t)) E: \equiv i \hbar \frac {1}{ \phi (t)} \frac { \partial }{ \partial t}( \phi (t)) E:≡iℏϕ(t)1​∂t∂​(ϕ(t)) and E: \equiv - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m \psi (x)} \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) E:≡−ℏ22mψ(x)∂2(ψ(x))∂x2+V(x) E: \equiv - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m \psi (x)} \frac { \partial ^2( \psi (x))}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) E:≡−2mψ(x)ℏ2​∂x2∂2(ψ(x))​+V(x) We have two equations: \begin {align*} \frac {d \phi }{dt} &= - \frac {iE}{ \hbar } \phi \\ - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac {d^2 \psi }{dx^2} + V \psi &= E \psi \end {align*} dϕdt=−iEℏϕ−ℏ22md2ψdx2+Vψ=Eψ \begin {align*} \frac {d \phi }{dt} &= - \frac {iE}{ \hbar } \phi \\ - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac {d^2 \psi }{dx^2} + V \psi &= E \psi \end {align*} dtdϕ​−2mℏ2​dx2d2ψ​+Vψ​=−ℏiE​ϕ=Eψ​ Now the partial differential equation has been reduced to two ordinary differential equations. The first one is easy to solve: \phi (t) = \phi (0)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } ϕ(t)=ϕ(0)e−iEt/ℏ \phi (t) = \phi (0)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } ϕ(t)=ϕ(0)e−iEt/ℏ Thus the complete solution is (note that the constant \phi (0)ϕ(0)\phi (0)ϕ(0) was absorbed into \psi (x)ψ(x)\psi (x)ψ(x)): \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ The second one is the time-independent Schrodinger equation, we can't go further unless we know the potential energy V(x)V(x)V(x)V(x).
Now we give a name to the time-independent Schrodinger equation.
A stationary state is a quantum state with all observables independent of time.

Thought the wave function is time-dependent, \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ \Psi (x,t) = \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } Ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ But if we compute the probability density, it is time-independent: | \Psi (x,t)|^2 = \psi ^*(x)e^{+iEt/ \hbar } \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } = | \psi (x)|^2 ∣Ψ(x,t)∣2=ψ∗(x)e+iEt/ℏψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ=∣ψ(x)∣2 | \Psi (x,t)|^2 = \psi ^*(x)e^{+iEt/ \hbar } \psi (x)e^{-iEt/ \hbar } = | \psi (x)|^2 ∣Ψ(x,t)∣2=ψ∗(x)e+iEt/ℏψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ=∣ψ(x)∣2 Hence the expectation value is constant in time. Then \langle p \rangle = 0⟨p⟩=0\langle p \rangle = 0⟨p⟩=0 all the time. Nothing happens in the stationary state.

frontmatter.title: Time-independent Schrodinger Equation › Conservation of energy

tree.mainmatter: This also means that the energy of the system is conserved. In classical mechanics, the total energy (kinetic + potential) of a system is called the Hamiltonian. H(x,p) = \frac {p^2}{2m} + V(x) H(x,p)=p22m+V(x) H(x,p) = \frac {p^2}{2m} + V(x) H(x,p)=2mp2​+V(x) In quantum mechanics, the Hamiltonian is an operator, obtained by substituting p \to -i \hbar \frac { \partial }{ \partial x}p→−iℏ∂∂xp \to -i \hbar \frac { \partial }{ \partial x}p→−iℏ∂x∂​: \hat {H} = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac { \partial ^2}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) H^=−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+V(x) \hat {H} = - \frac { \hbar ^2}{2m} \frac { \partial ^2}{ \partial x^2} + V(x) H^=−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+V(x) Thus the time-independent Schrodinger equation can be written as: \hat {H} \psi (x) = E \psi (x) H^ψ(x)=Eψ(x) \hat {H} \psi (x) = E \psi (x) H^ψ(x)=Eψ(x) The expectation value of the total energy gives the energy of the system: \begin {align*} \langle H \rangle &= \int \psi ^*(x) \hat {H} \psi (x)dx \\ &= \int \psi ^*(x)E \psi (x)dx \\ &= E \int | \psi (x)|^2dx \\ &= E \int | \Psi (x)|^2dx \\ &= E \end {align*} ⟨H⟩=∫ψ∗(x)H^ψ(x)dx=∫ψ∗(x)Eψ(x)dx=E∫∣ψ(x)∣2dx=E∫∣Ψ(x)∣2dx=E \begin {align*} \langle H \rangle &= \int \psi ^*(x) \hat {H} \psi (x)dx \\ &= \int \psi ^*(x)E \psi (x)dx \\ &= E \int | \psi (x)|^2dx \\ &= E \int | \Psi (x)|^2dx \\ &= E \end {align*} ⟨H⟩​=∫ψ∗(x)H^ψ(x)dx=∫ψ∗(x)Eψ(x)dx=E∫∣ψ(x)∣2dx=E∫∣Ψ(x)∣2dx=E​ and \begin {align*} \langle H^2 \rangle &= \int \psi ^*(x) \hat {H}^2 \psi (x)dx \\ &= E^2 \int | \psi (x)|^2 dx \\ &= E^2 \end {align*} ⟨H2⟩=∫ψ∗(x)H^2ψ(x)dx=E2∫∣ψ(x)∣2dx=E2 \begin {align*} \langle H^2 \rangle &= \int \psi ^*(x) \hat {H}^2 \psi (x)dx \\ &= E^2 \int | \psi (x)|^2 dx \\ &= E^2 \end {align*} ⟨H2⟩​=∫ψ∗(x)H^2ψ(x)dx=E2∫∣ψ(x)∣2dx=E2​ where \hat {H}^2 \psi = \hat {H}( \hat {H} \psi ) = \hat {H}(E \psi ) = E( \hat {H} \psi ) = E^2 \psi H^2ψ=H^(H^ψ)=H^(Eψ)=E(H^ψ)=E2ψ \hat {H}^2 \psi = \hat {H}( \hat {H} \psi ) = \hat {H}(E \psi ) = E( \hat {H} \psi ) = E^2 \psi H^2ψ=H^(H^ψ)=H^(Eψ)=E(H^ψ)=E2ψ Hence the variance of the energy is zero given by \Delta H = \sqrt { \langle H^2 \rangle - \langle H \rangle ^2} = 0 ΔH=⟨H2⟩−⟨H⟩2=0 \Delta H = \sqrt { \langle H^2 \rangle - \langle H \rangle ^2} = 0 ΔH=⟨H2⟩−⟨H⟩2​=0 This implies that the energy of the system is conserved.
